output.conclusion: By completing this course, you have gained a foundational understanding of chemical bonding, enabling you to predict and explain the properties of various substances. You are now equipped to explore more advanced chemistry topics.
output.introduction: Welcome to the fascinating world of chemical bonding! This course will introduce you to the fundamental principles that govern how atoms combine to form molecules and compounds. We'll explore the different types of bonds and their impact on the properties of matter.

chapters.description: A brief review of atomic structure, including protons, neutrons, and electrons. Focus on the electron configuration and its role in chemical bonding.
Understanding valence electrons and their importance in forming chemical bonds. How to determine the number of valence electrons for different elements.
Introduction to the octet rule and its significance in chemical bonding. Exceptions to the octet rule will be briefly mentioned.
Formation of ions (cations and anions) through the gain or loss of electrons. Examples of common ions and their charges.

modules.moduleTitle: The Octet Rule and Ion Formation

chapters.description: Definition of ionic bonding as the electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions. Examples of ionic compounds.
Overview of the properties of ionic compounds, such as high melting points, brittleness, and conductivity in solution.
Definition of covalent bonding as the sharing of electrons between atoms. Examples of covalent compounds.
Explanation of single, double, and triple covalent bonds and their relative strengths.
Introduction to electronegativity and its role in determining the polarity of covalent bonds. Examples of polar and nonpolar molecules.
Using electronegativity to determine if a bond is polar or nonpolar.
Introduction to metallic bonding and the 'sea of electrons' model. Properties of metals explained by metallic bonding.
A quick review of the different types of bonds discussed in the course (ionic, covalent, and metallic) and their key characteristics.
